content.definition: Syringomyelia is a chronic, progressive degenerative disorder of the spinal cord characterized by the formation of a fluid-filled, gliosis-lined cavity (syrinx) within the central canal, which expands to compress the anterior white commissure, leading to a dissociated sensory loss.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Expansion of the syrinx damages the decussating fibers of the [[spinothalamic_tract]] in the anterior white commissure first; may expand to anterior horns ([[lower_motor_neuron]] signs) or lateral horns ([[horner_syndrome]]).
  • Clinical Presentation: Classic "cape-like" bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities (usually C8-T1); fine touch and proprioception are preserved (dorsal columns spared).
  • Associations: Strongly associated with [[chiari_i_malformation]] (>90% of cases); also trauma, tumors, or idiopathic.
  • Diagnosis: MRI of the spine is the gold standard, revealing the cystic cavity.
  • USMLE Tip: Look for a patient with burns on their hands they didn't feel; often associated with cerebellar tonsillar ectopia.
content.takeAway: The hallmark of Syringomyelia is the dissociated sensory loss (loss of pain/temp with preserved touch) in a cape-like distribution, caused by the specific destruction of crossing spinothalamic fibers in the anterior white commissure.

content.definition: Epidural hematoma is a life-threatening collection of blood between the inner table of the skull and the dura mater, typically caused by traumatic rupture of the [[middle_meningeal_artery]] at the pterion, resulting in a rapidly expanding mass that can cause transtentorial herniation.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Blunt trauma to the temporal bone (pterion) ruptures the high-pressure [[middle_meningeal_artery]]; blood peels the dura off the skull.
  • Clinical Presentation: Classic "lucid interval" (loss of consciousness → recovery → rapid deterioration/coma); signs of [[increased_intracranial_pressure]], contralateral hemiparesis, and ipsilateral [[cn_iii_palsy]] ("down and out" pupil) due to uncal herniation.
  • Imaging: Non-contrast CT shows a biconvex (lentiform) hyperdensity that does NOT cross suture lines but CAN cross the midline (falx/tentorium).
  • Treatment: Emergent neurosurgical decompression (craniotomy).
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from [[subdural_hematoma]] (crescent shape, crosses sutures, bridging veins).
content.takeAway: Epidural hematoma is an arterial bleed (Middle Meningeal) defined by a biconvex shape on CT that is bounded by suture lines, often presenting with a classic lucid interval before rapid decompensation.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Temporal Bone Fracture] --> B[Middle Meningeal Artery Rupture]; B --> C[Arterial Bleeding]; C --> D[Dura Stripped from Skull]; D --> E[Rapid ICP Increase]; E --> F[Uncal Herniation];

content.definition: Glioblastoma (formerly GBM) is the most common and most malignant primary adult brain tumor of astrocytic origin (WHO Grade IV), characterized by rapid, infiltrative growth across the corpus callosum and histopathological features of microvascular proliferation and necrosis.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathology: Derived from [[astrocytes]] (GFAP positive); histology shows "pseudopalisading" pleomorphic tumor cells bordering central areas of necrosis and hemorrhage.
  • Imaging: MRI shows a ring-enhancing mass with central necrosis and surrounding vasogenic edema; often crosses the midline via the corpus callosum ("butterfly glioma").
  • Genetics: Associated with EGFR amplification and PTEN loss.
  • Prognosis: Extremely poor (median survival ~1 year).
  • USMLE Tip: "Pseudopalisading" necrosis and "butterfly" distribution are the buzzwords.
content.takeAway: Glioblastoma is the most aggressive primary brain tumor in adults, identified by its butterfly pattern on imaging and pseudopalisading necrosis on histology.

content.definition: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune inflammatory disorder of the central nervous system characterized by T-cell and antibody-mediated demyelination and axonal injury, resulting in neurologic deficits disseminated in both space (anatomy) and time.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Autoimmune destruction of [[oligodendrocytes]] and myelin sheaths; involves TH1 and TH17 cells, interferon-gamma, and macrophages.
  • Clinical Presentation: Highly variable; classic signs include [[optic_neuritis]] (painful vision loss), [[internuclear_ophthalmoplegia]] (MLF lesion), scanning speech, intention tremor, nystagmus (Charcot triad), and hemiparesis.
  • Diagnosis: MRI is gold standard (periventricular plaques/Dawson fingers); CSF shows oligoclonal IgG bands and elevated myelin basic protein.
  • Treatment: Acute flares: IV steroids; Chronic: Disease-modifying agents (e.g., [[beta_interferon]], glatiramer, natalizumab).
  • USMLE Tip: Bilateral [[internuclear_ophthalmoplegia]] (INO) in a young woman is virtually pathognomonic for MS. Symptoms often worsen with heat (Uhthoff phenomenon).
content.takeAway: Multiple Sclerosis is defined by autoimmune CNS demyelination leading to neurologic deficits separated by time and space, with oligoclonal bands and periventricular plaques as key diagnostic features.

content.definition: Horner syndrome is a clinical triad of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis caused by the interruption of the oculosympathetic pathway anywhere along its three-neuron chain from the hypothalamus to the eye.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Loss of sympathetic innervation to the superior tarsal muscle (ptosis), pupillary dilator (miosis), and facial sweat glands (anhidrosis).
  • Etiologies:
    - 1st Neuron (Central): Brainstem stroke (e.g., [[lateral_medullary_syndrome]]), syringomyelia.
    - 2nd Neuron (Preganglionic): [[pancoast_tumor]] (lung apex), cervical rib.
    - 3rd Neuron (Postganglionic): [[carotid_artery_dissection]] (painful, spares sweating), cavernous sinus pathology.
  • Diagnosis: Cocaine drops (normal eye dilates, Horner eye does not) or Apraclonidine (reversal of anisocoria).
  • USMLE Tip: If a patient has a Pancoast tumor (apical lung mass), look for ipsilateral Horner syndrome due to compression of the stellate ganglion.
content.takeAway: Horner syndrome signifies a lesion in the sympathetic chain, presenting with the classic triad of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis ipsilateral to the lesion.
